Lin was exuberant.
"Woweee! You look so hawt!", she exclaimed when she pulled up in her very red 1964 Covair.
On workdays, Lin wore slacks and blouses that always fit neatly. Tonight, she was decked off in black leather boots that reached her knees, a mini skirt and a green turtle-neck top.
After almost seven years of a work friendship, the most we had done by way of a casual evening was have a bottle of wine at the office. Our office.
The messiness worked for us though Lin's desk was always clean, her pens arranged in straight lines and writing paper stacked neatly, always toward her left.
The paper was held down by a stone that for some reason, she had sentimental attachment to. She had an obsession with vintage cars though she owned only one.

The tree was so many things: a space rocket, a monster, a wind-torn cliff from which I would dangle, saving humanity, one superhero feat at a time. It was just outside my window, all gnarled and battered, ugly, probably, to the jaded adult eye, but to me it was a monument, an evergreen promise of experience.

I saw eggs hatch on a nature show, the kind of thing Mom always encouraged me to watch, and knew there were tiny, helpless birds in there, waiting fro the right time to emerge, screaming and blind, into the great big Outside. I was entranced.Every day, I would climb to an adjacent branch to see if they had hatched. Mom would stand on the back porch, smiling and admonishing me to be careful, as I scampered up the tree. I felt like a big brother, looking over a crib made of twigs at my siblings, triplets, all cozy and safe by reason of altitude.
They were ugly-cute, tiny, screaming fuzzballs hollering for food, chastising their Mom for taking too long to come back with juicy insects or tasty seeds.

Mom bought me cheap binoculars so I could keep an eye on the little guys. I could sit in an upstairs window and just barely see the nest through the branches. It was my ritual to eat my lunch whilst checking their progress, mouth full of peanut butter and bread, peering though my binoculars, a happy little voyeur.

When I went to investigate, I realized it was one of the hatchlings! I ran up the back steps, yelling bloody murder."Mom! Mom! MOM! One of the birdies! Come quick!" my voice straining for volume, cracking with panic.

I didn't know what she meant right away. She had to explain that the little bird had fallen from the nest and died. She explained that even baby birds sometimes died because nature was 'just that way'. She told me she would take care of the 'body', a context in which I had never heard that word used before.I was inconsolable for a couple of days, earning all my favorite meals and even ice cream. It was my introduction to The End, the finality and permanence of death. I was heartbroken and I do not think I ever truly recovered, even now, in my adulthood.
I see Mom, quiet and still, nested among blankets and sheets, her silence even more distinct for the cacophony of the array of beeping electronic instruments.
I was wrong; I did not know heartbreak, truly, in its helpless, black depth, until it was my Momma Bird lying in the linen grass below me.
How does a person survive this? How is that their heart doesn't just cease to beat out of sorrow? The wings that bore me through childhood and beyond flutter no more.

"If I just drift off again, maybe when I'll wake up, maybe mum will be fine..." The thought was a childish intruder and an attempt at escape and it brought with it more pain than I could possibly have imagined feeling 24 hours ago. I shut my eyes against it all.
